description:
With this Meetup, we want to get all people in Belgium together that are interested in Graph Database technology. We want to provide a forum for people to get started with the technology, and also take the time to share experiences, real-life case studies, best practices and advanced use cases. This meetup will be the first of a series of meetings, which we will plan in the next few weeks.

Agenda:
10h-10h30 - people arrive, and will be offered a cup of coffee/something else
10h30-11h30 - presentation by Jim Webber, Chief Scientist at Neo Technology. Jim will be introducing graph technology, but thanks to his wealth of experience, can also go into a deep dive with the attendees if necessary.
11h30-12h - questions and answers, planning of next meetup
12-13h - sandwiches and drinks,
how_to_find_us: See http://goo.gl/maps/OMynq for a map. Le Pain Quotidien is very easy to reach by train: it is located 20m from the "new" entrance to Antwerp Central Station. There is also a public parking right underneath: http://goo.gl/BpDpD.
name: Get all Belgian Graphistas together

description:
When: Monday, 12th of November, 2012

Where: Congrescentrum Het Pand, Onderbergen 1, 9000 Gent

What: a specific workshop to enable a better functional and technical understanding of what Graph Databases like Neo4j can do for BioTech organisations

Audience: technical architects, technical consultants, project managers, and technically interested business owners

Agenda:

[masked]am Registration

[masked]am Introduction and welcome Lennart Martens

[masked]am GraphDB overview, Michael Hunger, Neo Technology Community team

[masked]am Use case 1 presentation: metaproteomics Lennart Martens & team

[masked]am break

[masked]am Neo4j APIs: how to use a graph database, Michael Hunger, Neo Technology Community team

11.15am-12.00am Bio4j presentation by Pablo Pareja, Era7

12.00am-1.00pm LUNCH

[masked]pm Biograph.be presentation Anthony Liekens, University of Antwerp

[masked]pm The power of graphs to analyze biological data. Davy Suvee, Janssen Pharmaceutica

[masked]pm Workshop phase 1

Reactome integration
- task 1: initiate neo4reactome
- task 2: create DAO
- task 3: Import reactome into graphdb Lennart Martens & team, Neo4j community team

[masked]pm Coffee break

[masked]pm Workshop phase 2: Reactome analysis
- task 4: paths between two compounds
- task 5: cypher playground Lennart Martens & team, Neo4j community team

[masked]pm USER Questions, discussion, closing remarks Moderated

[masked]pm Reception
name: WORKSHOP: Graph Databases in Life Sciences

description:
During this evening session, we would like to share and discuss a number of graph database case studies. We have 2 cases lined up for you:

- Ignaz Wanders of ArchiMiddle will be presenting, demonstrating and discussing their use of Graph Databases for better managing real complex Service Oriented Architecture networks, and doing impact analyses on these networks.

- Willem-Paul Stuurman of Knollenstein will be presenting their use of a Graph Database for creating the next generation recruitment advertising system.

The session will start at 6pm with a light dinner, and end around 9pm with a nice cold beer.

Looking forward to seeing you there!
name: Graph Database Case Studies - in cooperation with Archimiddle.com

description:
Lots of people - specifically IT architects, project and IT managers - have contacted us to get an "introduction" style presentation with regards to graphs and graph databases. So that's what we want to provide in this session!

During this session, we will present, demonstrate and discuss the initial graph database context for people not necessarily familiar with the subject. Afterwards, we will have the opportunity to network over a light lunch.
name: Intro to Graph Databases

description:
As Peter Neubauer and Michael Hunger are in town, we thought it would be nice to have a meetup the day before FOSDEM - GraphDevRoom

We have a number of topics that we could talk about and wanted to know which of those would be interesting for you:


Spring Data Neo4j - Object Graph Mapping made easy
Neo4j Spatial - handling geographic information in a graph, Geo-APIs, OpenStreetMap
Structr CMS - a novel CMS built on top of Neo4j
Neo4j in the wild - interesting real-life applications of Neo4j


Please state your interest so that we can prepare accordingly.
name: Discuss some cool Graph Topics

description:
Lots of people have requested to get their hands dirty with a production ready graph database like Neo4j. That's why we have decided to offer a cheap, hands-on and interesting tutorial course for Neo4j, together with our partners, Xebia. The training is in the Netherlands, at about 1.5hrs from Antwerpen. If a couple of people from Belgium want to go - we may be able to carpool.

** PLEASE NOTE THAT THERE IS NO REGISTRATION FOR THIS EVENT ON MEETUP, SEE BELOW **

Please register for this course at http://info.neotechnology.com/0307-amsterdam-register.html - you will have to pay a small fee to cover the costs of the training.

Looking forward to seeing you there!
name: Hands-On Neo4j Tutorial

description:
Cypher is a graph query language used in Neo4j. Much like SQL, it's a declarative language used for querying databases. In this talk, Andrés Taylor, a former SQL DBA and Cypher lead at Neo Technology, will compare and contrast the two.

What does an join look like in Cypher? What about an left outer join? There are a lot of similarities between the two - Cypher is heavily influenced by SQL. We'll talk about what these common concepts are, and of course, we'll talk about the differences, what Cypher gives you that SQL leaves you wanting. Come along and see how Neo4j and Cypher can make your daily grind much easier and more fun.
name: Graph Database Queries: Cypher for SQL addicts

description:
THERE ARE STILL SEATS AVAILABLE!

Please register at:

http://graphcafeantwerpen.eventbrite.com

 

Graphs are getting a lot of new attention, as part of the industry’s drive for NO-SQL, big data (whatever that means) and data science. Today however, we feel that’s only the “lucky few” that have seen the light and are experimenting with Graphs and Graph databases. And we want to spread the word - make this the biggest thing since hot water, sliced bread, and tables/stools.

So here’s the idea: on 12th of June 2013, we want to get all graphistas together for a fun and exciting evening of graphs - and beer. The concept is that of a “Knowledge Café”, where we just put a bunch of tables in a nice venue, and have lightning talks every 15 minutes to spice up the conversations. We would do it in a nice location: Afspanning De Hand, next to Brouwerij De Koninck, in Antwerp - just so that we can benefit of some beer tastings as well :) …

What could YOU do for this event? Well, we have a couple of ideas!
- you could come! Everyone is welcome, provided that they register beforehand.
- you could host a knowledge table, to discuss and explain to other people what you have been doing with graphs
- you could do a lightning talk - no more than 5minutes, 5 slides!
- you could - and this is the important part - bring your friends and colleagues. If you do, we will have a nice little something for you to remember the night by - just as a token of appreciation.

Let us know if you have any other ideas - would love to have you there!
how_to_find_us: The event will take place in the big room on the 1st floor, above the pub/restaurant
name: Graph Café

description:
Since many people have been asking for some graph modeling guidelines, we are going to spend this meetup talking about best practices, pitfalls and techniques to get you going with a graph-based datamodel. 

The agenda is straightforward:

• 18h-18h30: Welcome - we will provide some light food and drinks

• 18h30-19h30: Presentation by Mark Needham, Neo Technology

• 19h30-20h: Q&A, discussion

• 20h-21: Networking and drinks.

Our friends at Archimiddle have (again) kindly offered to provide the location - so we look forward to seeing you all there!
name: Graph Modeling Do's and Don'ts

description: As you may know, FOSDEM again has a great lineup for graphistas this year. Look at https://fosdem.org/2014/schedule/track/graph_processing/ and see the amazing talks by some international and well-known speakers. Would love to meet everyone for a drink afterwards at a typical Brussels bar downtown - let's have a Gueuze and connect!
name: Debrief after FOSDEM Graph Devroom

description:
Our Belgian Graph Database meetup was long overdue. We are going to get together in a nice pub again, have some case studies presented to us, and taste some beers. These are the cases that we have lined up today, but we can always add more:

• Pieter Cailliau from Tomtom will explain how they used neo4j in their map production system's quality checks. Really interesting use case.


• Archimiddle will explain some of their recent work around football data.


• Rik (me) will talk about some fun use cases that involve Abba. Hang on to your seats.


If anyone else is interested in doing a talk, then please let me know as soon as you can!

Looking forward to seeing you there!

Cheers

Rik
how_to_find_us: Behind the Brouwerij De Koninck, close to the Antwerp Ringroad and walking distance from Berchem Station
name: Graph Database cases: Tomtom, Football, and ... Abba

description:
For our November meetup, we will be covering three different graph database case studies from local people here in Belgium. We currently have 3 talks lined up:

• We are graciously hosted at Nucleus for this meetup - and they will also give a talk about their use of Neo4j in a Configuration Management Database use case.

• PingValue is developing social shopping networks to offer products that people like to people visiting their site. They use Neo4j for recommendations / social aspects.


• Eggs & Rabbit Holes is reinventing bartering for the 21st century - going from the 1 on 1 barter model to a n to n system. They are using Neo4j as the database engine underneath.


Should be a fun discussion.

For those of you who come by car, we'd advise against placing your car on the parking behind the office building, you can park your car along the road in front of the Nucleus office (the North Trade Building) and then take a really short walk to the right side entrance of the building (see http://note.io/1C8NznN for a picture). If you do want to place your car on the parking behind the building you'll need a coin or badge get off the parking.
how_to_find_us: Nucleus' offices are located at the ground floor, just to the left of the reception in the main hall. Hope to see you all there!
name: Belgian Graph Database cases
